data.title: Post Line-ups - Cricket at the 1948 Olympics | Match 12 - What on earth happened back there?!
data.meta_description:
Fantastically done by our bowlers. Relentless pressure from start to finish.
Thanks for a great season, enjoyed it once again @VC the slogger .

data.text:
Cricket at the Olympics

Berlin 1936​

Cricket at the Olympics - Berlin 1936​

The Olympic Games will finally be hosted by Berlin in 1936, twenty years after the 1916 Games which were set to take place in the city but had to be cancelled due to the outbreak of the Great War in 1914. They won the bid to host the Games in the 29th IOC session in Barcelona in 1931, eventually beating the latter's bid to also host the games for the very first time. Of course, this was two years prior to the events which saw the Nazis led by Adolf Hitler come to power and gain control over all aspects of German life as a result of the Enabling Act of 1933, and the subsequent death of President Hindenburg in 1934. There had been talk of shifting the games to another city in a different country due to several nations threatening to boycott the 1936 Games in protest to the Nazi regime's blatantly racist and anti-semitic ideologies which have led to several ethnic groups, no more so than the Jews, to be ostracised and denied basic human rights throughout the country.

However, tensions have been somewhat calmed after assurances from Hitler's regime that athletes of Jewish origin and other ethnicities would be allowed to compete, and the city 'cleansed' of racist signs and slogans for the duration of the Games. The US Olympic committee publicly accepted the invitation to go to the Games in September 1934, thereby halting any IOC attempts to quietly revise the decision to host the event in Berlin. Nevertheless, several athletes from across the globe have remained unconvinced and some individual Jewish athletes from a number of countries have chosen to boycott the event, including Sidney Kiel from South Africa, Milton Green and Norman Cahners from the United States. But a good many such as the US Olympic committee president Avery Brundage have lended their support for the Games to continue in Berlin arguing that "politics has no place in sports", and that success on the field of play would only go a long way towards undermining these pathetic notions of 'Aryan supremacy' and racist propaganda being spread by the Nazis. Only one nation has boycotted the 1936 Games, and not for the reasons expected - the Olympic council of Ireland have decided against sending any of their athletes to participate after the IOC insisted they needed to keep their teams restricted to the Irish Free State rather than representing the entire island of Ireland.

The total number of participants for cricket at the 1936 Games stands at 16 - the same as the 1932 Games in Los Angeles four years previously. They are (in alphabetical order): Argentina, Australia, Bermuda, Canada, Chile, Republic of China, Costa Rica, Egypt, Germany, Great Britain, India, Netherlands, New Zealand, South Africa, United States of America and the West Indies. Bermuda, having missed the 1932 Games, are set to make a comeback after a gap of 8 years whilst first timers Costa Rica come in place of1928 Bronze medalists Ireland who chose to boycott the 1936 Games. Germany, the host nation will be playing cricket for the second Olympic Games on the trot after having made a brief but unspectacular first appearance in the Los Angeles in 1932 where they were soundly beaten by a strong Indian team fresh from having gained Test status. It will be interesting to see how they come to terms with playing a cricket tournament at home in the presence of leaders who consider the game 'effeminate' and 'insufficiently violent' for Germans. They will be able to call upon the services of overseas stars such Jack Nitschke, Hans Ebeling and Otto Nothling once again. The trio were initially reluctant to play under a team brandishing the Red Swastika flag of a Nazi-dominated Germany, but were eventually convinced by the efforts of Felix Menzel and German sports minister Hans von Tschammer und Osten.

The format for the 1936 tournament is along the same lines as 1932 where 8 teams out of 16 qualified for the group stages consisting of 4 teams in each group, followed by the knockouts and bronze playoff. Except this time 6 nations - namely Test nations Australia, Great Britain, New Zealand, South Africa, West Indies and also hosts Germany have been given direct access to the group stages. Meanwhile, 10 other nations namely Test cricket's newest addition India, reigning Bronze medalists Canada, Argentina, Egypt, United States, Netherlands, Chile, Republic of China, Costa Rica and Bermuda are to battle it out over three rounds of knockout matches for two available berths at the group stages. A reason behind this slight change in format is said to be the mismatch between Australia and Chile in the first match of the 1932 Olympic Games in Los Angeles, where the Australians triumphed by a ginormous 252-run margin on the back of Don Bradman's superhuman 264* off just 174 balls. According to the IOC, such matches though good for the record books tend to degrade the quality of the competition and could be prevented with a somewhat less inclusive format.

Two venues are to be used for hosting cricket matches - one being the Olympiastadion, one of the biggest stadiums in the world with a gigantic capacity of 100,000. The other will be the Stadion am Gesundbrunnen, dwarfed by the Olympiastadion in terms of capacity at a still somewhat impressive 35,000 available seats. The Olympiastadion will host all the matches of Group B, which involves hosts Germany, reigning Gold medalists Great Britain and 1924 Silver medalists West Indies, along with the second semi-final, the bronze playoff and the final. The Gesundbrunnen stadium aka Hertha-BSC Field will host all the qualifying and Group A matches featuring reigning Silver medalists Australia, South Africa, New Zealand to go with the first semi-final. It will be interesting to see what new sporting achievements lie in store as the modern Olympics enters it's fourth decade of existence.​

Fixtures & Results

Qualifying Round 1

QM 1 - Chile v Costa Rica at Gesundbrunnen - Chile won by 60 runs

QM 2 - Republic of China v Bermuda at Gesundbrunnen - Republic of China won by 2 wickets (with 69 balls remaining)

Qualifying Round 2

Match 3 - Canada v Chile at Gesundbrunnen - Canada won by 6 wickets (with 2 balls remaining)

Match 4 - United States v India at Gesundbrunnen - India won by 165 runs

Match 5 - Argentina v Republic of China at Gesundbrunnen - Argentina won by 19 runs

Match 6 - Egypt v Netherlands at Gesundbrunnen - Egypt won by 2 runs

Qualifying Round 3

Qualifier 1 - Canada v India at Gesundbrunnen - India won by 7 wickets (with 18 balls remaining)

Qualifier 2 - Argentina v Egypt at Gesundbrunnen - Egypt won by 32 runs

Group stages

Round 1

Australia v India at Gesundbrunnen - Australia won by 7 wickets (with 8 balls remaining)

South Africa v New Zealand at Gesundbrunnen - South Africa won by 8 wickets (with 26 balls remaining)

Great Britain v Egypt at Olympiastadion - Great Britain won by 147 runs

Germany v West Indies at Olympiastadion - West Indies won by 53 runs

Round 2

Germany v Egypt at Olympiastadion - Germany won by 5 runs

Great Britain v West Indies at Olympiastadion - Great Britain won by 8 wickets (with 124 balls remaining)

India v New Zealand at Gesundbrunnen - New Zealand won by 3 wickets (with 15 balls remaining)

Australia v South Africa at Gesundbrunnen - Australia won by 1 wicket (with 20 balls remaining)

Round 3

New Zealand v Australia at Gesundbrunnen - Australia won by 6 wickets (with 107 balls remaining)

South Africa v India at Gesundbrunnen - South Africa won by 5 wickets (with 5 balls remaining)

West Indies v Egypt at Olympiastadion - West Indies won by 2 wickets (with 10 balls remaining)

Germany v Great Britain at Olympiastadion - Great Britain won by 193 runs

Semi-finals

SF 1 - Australia v West Indies at Gesundbrunnen - Australia won by 51 runs

SF 2 - Great Britain v South Africa at Olympiastadion - South Africa won by 5 wickets (with 21 balls remaining)

Bronze playoff

West Indies v Great Britain at Olympiastadion - West Indies won by 5 runs

Final

Australia v South Africa at Olympiastadion - Australia won by 54 runs​

Summary​

The 1936 Summer Olympics, officially known as the Games of the XI Olympiad, were held in Berlin, Nazi Germany. Berlin, who were supposed to host the 1916 Olympics that were cancelled due to the Great War, won the bid to host the Games ahead of Barcelona at the 29th IOC session on 26 April 1931. This was two years prior to the events which saw the Nazis led by Adolf Hitler rise to power in Germany, which transformed the former Weimar Republic into Nazi Germany, a one-party dictatorship based on the totalitarian and autocratic ideology of National Socialism. This along with the anti-Semitic policies instituted by the Nazis led to the IOC holding private discussions among its delegates about changing the decision to hold the Games in Berlin. However, assurances from Hitler's regime that Jewish athletes would be allowed to compete on a German Olympic team and the city 'cleansed' of racist signs and slogans for the duration of the Games, along with the US Olympic Committee's decision to accept the invitation to go to Berlin halted any further attempts to change the venue of the Games to a different country. US Olympic Committee president Avery Brundage, a main supporter of the Games being held in Nazi Germany argued that "politics has no place in sport".

Nevertheless, the 1936 Games faced boycotts from individual Jewish athletes such as Sidney Kiel from South Africa, Albert Wolff from France, Milton Green and Norman Cahners from the United States, and the Ireland Olympic Committee who withdrew after the IOC insisted they needed to keep their teams restricted to the Irish Free State rather than representing the entire island of Ireland. Spain also chose to boycott the 1936 Games and tried to organize a 'People's Olympiad' as a parallel event in Barcelona, with disastrous results due to the outbreak of the Spanish Civil War just one day before the event was set to start. A total of 49 nations participated in the opening ceremony at the Berlin Olympiastadion (Olympic stadium), with every nation at the parade except for the United States lowering their flag as they passed the Reich Chancellor Adolf Hitler. The 1936 opening ceremony also saw the first instance of the torch relay which was carried out by German long distance runner Fritz Schilgen. Hitler officially declared the Games open from his own box.

Of the 49 participating nations, 16 participated in the sport of cricket - including host nation Germany who made their cricketing debut at the 1932 Games in Los Angeles, and Olympic debutants Costa Rica. The full list of participants (in alphabetical order) included Argentina, Australia, Bermuda, Canada, Chile, Republic of China, Costa Rica, Egypt, Germany, Great Britain, India, Netherlands, New Zealand, South Africa, United States of America and the West Indies. Bermuda, having missed the 1932 Games made a comeback after a gap of 8 years replacing 1928 Bronze medalists Ireland who decided to boycott the event. Brazil, who participated in cricket in every Olympics since their debut at the 1920 Olympics in Antwerp also decided against sending over a cricket team this time. The format for the 1936 tournament was along the same lines as 1932 where 8 teams out of 16 qualified for the group stages consisting of 4 teams in each group, followed by the knockouts and bronze playoff. Except this time 6 nations - namely Test nations Australia, Great Britain, New Zealand, South Africa, West Indies and also hosts Germany had been given direct access to the group stages. Meanwhile, 10 other nations namely Test cricket's newest addition India, reigning Bronze medalists Canada, Argentina, Egypt, United States, Netherlands, Chile, Republic of China, Costa Rica and Bermuda were made to battle it out over three rounds of knockout matches for two available berths at the group stages.

A reason behind this slight change in format was said to have been the mismatch between Australia and Chile in the first match of the 1932 Olympic Games in Los Angeles, where the Australians triumphed by a ginormous 252-run margin on the back of Don Bradman's superhuman 264* off just 174 balls. According to the IOC, such matches though good for the record books degraded the quality of the competition and could be prevented with a somewhat less inclusive format. Germany's direct promotion to the group stages despite being neither a Test nation nor a renowned Olympic nation in the sport of cricket at the expense of India, Test cricket's newest addition in 1932 raised quite a few eyebrows within cricketing circles, with some calling the IOC's decision 'disgraceful' and done purely to spare the Nazis of the embarrassment of bowing out before reaching the group stages of the competition. Some also claimed that cricket's integrity as a sport had now been compromised for promoting a regime that openly encourages racism and anti-Semitism, who also consider the sport 'effeminate' and 'insufficiently violent' for Germans. It was dubbed one of the 'darkest' days in cricket's history.

In a bid to outdo the Los Angles Games of 1932, a gigantic 100,000-seat track and field stadium called the Berlin Olympiastadion aka Olympic Stadium was constructed in the city under Hitler's orders and unveiled during the 1936 Games. The Olympiastadion and the Stadion am Gesundbrunnen aka Hertha BSC Field, with a capacity of 35,000 were the two venues used for cricket matches in the 1936 tournament. The first qualifying round saw Chile take on debutants Costa Rica at the Hertha BSC Field; the former registering a convincing 60-run victory - incidentally their first ever in the Olympics, with John Jackson recording the first ever Olympic century by a player from Latin America during the match scoring an unbeaten 119 off 163 balls. Bermuda were overcome by the Republic of China in the second match of the round by a narrow 2-wicket margin. The latter progressed to the second qualifying round alongside Chile.

Chile and the Republic of China, the two teams to qualify from the first qualifying round met their match in the second qualifying round when they took on Canada and Argentina respectively. Canada beat Chile by a comfortable 6-wicket margin with only 2 balls to spare in the match on the back of half-centuries from Reg Wenman and Clarke Bell. India, who were somewhat controversially made to slog it out in the preliminaries despite being a Test nation showed every bit of their frustration at the IOC's decision by crushing former Olympic cricket giants United States by a massive 165-run margin. Having posted a commanding 257 on the back on half-centuries from debutant Vijay Merchant and veterans CK Nayudu and Wazir Ali, they went on to bowl out the Americans for a paltry 92 - of which 52 were scored by Kenneth 'Bam Bam' Weekes off just 40 balls on debut; their innings containing a record 6 ducks. The Republic of China put in a far more respectable performance than the Americans against 1920 Bronze medalists Argentina, but proved no match for their potent bowling attack, falling short by 19 runs. Egypt defeated the Netherlands in the last match of the round by a mere 2 runs to progress to the third and final qualifying round alongside Canada, India and Argentina. It was to be their final hurdle before the group stages featuring the other five Test nations and Germany.

The Indians' fierce desire to forge an identity for themselves on the world stage after more than a century under British rule proved too much for 1932 Bronze medalists Canada, who had assembled what many including former US Olympic Gold-winning captain John Lester considered to be the best cricket team to emerge from the continent of North America. They beat Canada by a comprehensive 7-wicket margin to qualify for the group stages of the competition alongside Egypt, who stunned former Bronze medalists Argentina by 32 runs to finish in the top eight of an Olympic tournament for the first time in their 24-year association with the sport. Clem Gibson, Argentina's second highest wicket-taker after Herbert Dorning and the Olympics' fourth highest overall after Dorning, Bart King and Clarrie Grimmett retired at the end of the match with 29 wickets at an average of 18.55 and a useful 190 runs at 23.75 from 16 matches between 1920 and 1936. He was also the only bowler apart from Bill Lockwood and King to claim two five-wicket hauls in a career, and one of only three players to claim a hat-trick in the Olympics in 1932 against South Africa - incidentally the only hat-trick recorded till date against a Test-playing nation.

The 8 teams making it to the group stages were split into two groups each - Group A consisting of Australia, India, New Zealand and South Africa which was called 'the group of death' due to its containing four Test nations; Group B on the other hand consisted of Egypt, Germany, Great Britain and the West Indies, a relatively easier group to determine with two Test nations and two amateur nations. Australia dominated Group A with 3 victories from their 3 matches - beating India by 7 wickets, South Africa by just 1 wicket and New Zealand by 6 wickets to finish atop their group despite Don Bradman looking distinctly off color with the bat following a century against India in their first match. South Africa, who came within touching distance beating Australia finished at second place after recording victories over New Zealand by 8 wickets and India by 5 wickets. New Zealand recorded their only victory against India by 3 wickets, their first since the 1924 Games in Paris and just their second overall in 36 years of participation in the Olympics. It wasn't enough to guarantee them a semi-final berth however; India on the other hand couldn't quite match up to their performances in the preliminaries and finished winless in the group stages. Australia and South Africa therefore became the two teams to qualify for the semi-finals from Group A.

If Australia were dominant in Group A, Great Britain were utterly merciless in Group B with crushing victories in every single one of their matches courtesy of one man - Hedley Verity. The left-arm tweaker from Yorkshire clinically bamboozled all comers by claiming 8 wickets at an unbelievable average of 5.25 whilst conceding at an even more astonishing 1.74 runs per over from his 3 matches during the group stages. It came as no surprise that Great Britain reigned supreme with a 147-run victory against Egypt, an 8-wicket victory over the West Indies and a 193-run mauling of hosts Germany at the Olympiastadion, which was dubbed their greatest humiliation at the international level since the Treaty of Versailles. They finished their group unbeaten and thoroughly unchallenged to qualify for the semi-finals alongside the second-placed West Indies, who recorded victories over Germany by 53 runs and Egypt by 2 wickets. George Headley, the Panama-born black Jamaican played an instrumental role in both their victories by scoring 107 and 72 against Germany and Egypt respectively. His century against the Germans at the Olympiastadion in the presence of several high-ranking Nazi officials undermined their racist propaganda and notions of 'Aryan supremacy', prompting many to compare him with American track and field athlete Jesse Owens who won four Gold medals for the 100m, 200m, long jump and 4x100m relay events in the presence of Hitler to earn the respect of the entire world, except perhaps his own president.

Germany finished a respectable third place in Group B by registering a thrilling 5-run victory over Egypt, who finished winless in the group stages. Both teams fell well short of a semi-final berth but completed their most successful campaigns till date in the Olympics. The first semi-final between Australia and the West Indies saw the former post 248/0 off their 50 overs with openers Jack Fingleton and Bill Brown recording centuries, and more interestingly finishing with the same exact score i.e 118. This marked the first instance of a team batting through the entire length of 50 overs without losing a single wicket in the Olympics. Australia won by 51 runs to qualify for their fifth straight Olympic final since the disbandment of Australasia in 1920. The second semi-final between Great Britain and South Africa saw the latter register their first ever victory against the mother country in three encounters at the Olympics dating back to 1924. South Africa, as a result qualified for their first ever Olympic final in 32 years of participation and went one better than their previous best result which was a Bronze medal at the 1908 Olympic Games in London. Great Britain and the West Indies were left to battle it out for Bronze.

West Indies defeated Great Britain by a narrow 5-run margin to claim just their second medal for the sport in the form of Bronze, and their first since winning a Silver medal at the 1924 Olympic Games in Paris. George Headley was at the forefront of their victorious effort once again, with an unbeaten 88 off 128 balls in an innings where only one other batsman - his close friend Clarence Passailaigue from Jamaica reached double figures. West Indies posted 198/9 off their 50 overs largely on the back of the two batsmen sharing in a 121-run partnership for the 4th wicket. It proved enough in the testing conditions for batsmen at the Olympiastadion, as Great Britain could manage only 193 in response. Headley finished the tournament as it's leading run-scorer ahead of even Bradman with 305 runs at an average of 76.25 from 5 matches compared to the latter's 231 runs at 77.00 from 5 matches, of which he batted in 4 innings. He was given the nickname "Atlas" for the way in which he almost single-handedly carried a faltering West Indian lineup to a Bronze medal on the back of his performances, in a manner similar to the Greek Titan of legend with the unenviable task of carrying the sky on his shoulders for eternity.

In the final, Australia having won the toss elected to bat and posted an intimidating 238/7 off their 50 overs on the back of a century from Don Bradman, who finally regained his lost touch in time for the most important game of the competition. He became the first player in the history of the Olympics to bring up 1000 career runs during his brilliant innings of 110 coming off just 112 balls - the 6th instance of him scoring a century in the Olympics; the next best being only 2 by retried South African batsman Herbie Taylor and West Indies' talisman George Headley. South Africa never really looked like chasing down Australia's total with Bill O'Reilly opening the bowling and conceding 0 runs off the first 4 overs of his spell, which ultimately read 10-3-17-1. He was quite ably supported by Clarrie Grimmett in his final Olympic match, Ernie McCormick and Chuck Fleetwood-Smith - all of whom picked 2 wickets apiece to keep South Africa restricted to just 184/9 off their 50 overs. Australia emerged victorious by 54 runs to claim their sixth Gold medal for cricket in ten Olympic tournaments dating back to 1896. South Africa finished with their first ever Silver medal for the sport and West Indies with Bronze to finish proceedings. Great Britain, who won a medal for cricket in every Games since 1896 endured their first ever medal-less campaign in 40 years of the Olympics. They still had something to cheer as Hedley Verity beat Headley, Bradman and the tournament's leading wicket-taker Ernie McCormick to win Player of the Tournament for his 10 wickets at an average of 8.90 and an economy rate of 2.02 from 5 matches in the competition. Australia's all-time leading wicket-taker Clarrie Grimmett retired at the end of the match with 34 wickets at an average of 17.38 from 21 matches between 1912 and 1936 - finishing behind only Herbert Dorning and Bart King on the list of leading wicket-takers in the Olympics. He was joined in retirement by longtime team-mate Bert Oldfield, the most prolific wicket-keeper in the history of the Olympics with 22 dismissals to his name from 20 matches between 1920 and 1936. ​
